attachments.text: Asana puts conversations & tasks together, so you can get more done with less effort. Do Great Things with Asana.

text: <@U0A6WE73P>: your lab uses Asana? How many active users? Thoughts from the team use perspective?

(after abandoning Trello, I moved back to a heavily-templated "2015 Week XY" Google Doc—freshly copied each week, manual task promotion, somewhat limited for planning anything further than a week out, but 100% _not_ fiddly)
<!channel>: Asana looks awesome for individual project planning! definitely check it out! (free for teams up to 15 people)

<@U0A6T0LNT>: For individual projects, make sure you're using the "Personal Projects" workspace.  There isn't a built-in solution for copying projects between workspaces, so I spent 10 minutes earlier today copying tasks from the workspace they have you create in the tutorial.
(Unless you're planning on sharing those tasks with other people - Personal Projects is precisely for individual project planning, so it's a workspace of 1.)
iiinteresting. so far I've only put work-related stuff into it, but I'll check that out
'personal projects' is just simplified by not asking you to assign tasks?
oops sorry, my last message should have been on this thread.  Still getting used to Slack.
(oh hey, I can delete other peoples' messages)

Asana is nice so far.  The way my lab uses it (6 grad students, 1 postdoc (me) and 1 PI) is so that everyone can keep abreast of what everyone else is doing without necessarily going through tiresome lab presentations every week).
I think that's a brilliant use case - we waste so much time on pointless updates

At first it seemed really creepy and voyeuristic, because I can see the task lists of everyone on my team.  I thought it would be weird to be able to Big Brother on my labmates-- see if they were completing tasks on time, etc.  But in practice no one does that I don't think.

It's easy because when I meet with my supervisor we can add tasks together and then assign them during the meeting.  Then you can use the Personal Projects tab if you're working on something private or unrelated.
very very cool, hoping I can convince my lame coworkers how cool this is

I only have one project up on my lab's space, but several on my Personal space (finishing the manuscripts from my dissertation, applying for faculty jobs, etc all go under this heading because I don't necessarily want my labmates to know/be bothered by this)
in the free version, can I create different workspaces and invite different people to different workspaces?
(do you use free or paid?)

The only bad thing so far is that you can't infinitely subdivide a task.  Tasks get subtasks, but you can't make sub-subtasks.  You can make comments on tasks though, and attach files (but again, the nesting functionality is only so-so... when you attach a file you can't make a comment, and you can't situate the attached file with a specific subtask-- only with the task at large)
Not sure.  Free I think, but it was in place when I arrived-- they've been using it for several months at least
Upper right hand corner of the interface there's a menu, with "More >", and "Create New Workspace".
Click it!

I wonder if the subdivision structure is by design?  For task lists, often it can be tempting to create "tasks" which are large in scope, but that isn't very conducive to a "To do list" paradigm of workflow management.
figuring out how to rename a workspace...
ah, there it is - under settings
Yep!
The tutorials actually propose a type of workflow management using "sections", which seems to be really effective for a variety of things.
yeah, I've already started playing with sections
'stuff to do in the lab' versus 'stuff to write', &etc

As for apartments: I have a bunch of clear plastic tubs, a few boxes, some metal rack shelves, and a bed frame large enough to put plastic tubs underneath. 

Basically I unpack clothing, computer stuff, kitchen gear, and maybe the top layer from an office supply box. Everything else lives in a plastic tub until needed and then when i move there is minimal repacking.
Obviously works best if one moves a lot...

text: Sounds about right

Expanding from <#C0A6SMGR4> : any suggestion for an e-reading solution for academic papers?  Tabletwise, all I have is a Kindle Fire, which is shitty for reading and annotating PDFs.  I'd love a solution that would allow A) fitting the entire page on the screen at once and still being readable and B) nice intuitive handwritten annotation ability, for underlining and scribbling in margins etc.  Hopefully on the lower budget side; I don't want to drop $600 on a tablet but would be willing to spend around $200 (used is okay).   Right now my system is printing off journal papers and organizing them topically in binders, which obviously makes searching tough.

Brandon and I have looked at this a reasonable amount, and there's really no killer app out there right now.  My personal software of choice for literature management is Zotero, which integrates best with Firefox, but also connects easily with Chrome and Safari via an extra standalone app.  This is really useful for me because it makes the step of "marking a paper for future reference in an organized fashion" a super simple process (connectors for most major publisher websites, arXiv, metadata by DOI or ISBN, etc.), but its downfall is that it doesn't support mobile out of the box, and doesn't support electronic annotation.
My strategy is to use Zotero for general archival / reference purposes, and to print out and sort papers that I'm interacting with heavily and want to annotate.

I believe Brandon is using Mendeley, which is another solid option that has better support for document annotation, but less integration with web browsers as of the last time I looked at it.  Also, its support for mobile was likewise crap in the past.  I also don't like the fact that it was purchased by publishing titan Elsevier a few years ago.  Perhaps Brandon has more to say about the current state of affairs, since I haven't interacted with it for a year or two at least.

I think that a major problem with the e-reading issue is that most papers are distributed in PDF format, which doesn't provide facilities for rescaling to different display formats.  I don't think that anyone has come up with a solution to that yet.

Perhaps somebody needs to design an extended e-reader format (e.g. like MOBI for Kindle, but better) that supports a broader selection of scientific typesetting components but also allows display customization?

I feel like it wouldn't be too difficult to make a new LaTeX compiler which produces a different output format based on this idea (latex vs. pdflatex vs. mobilatex).  But perhaps that's a discussion for <#C0A6T3LQP>.

It's impossible to read papers on an e reader. A very large tablet is motion in the right direction, but it has to be huge to be big enough to fit a prayer at decent scale. Annotating without a real keyboard is a nightmare.

I use Zotero for casual lowspeed projects that don't require a lot of annotation. It supports WebDav and its not too hard to set up a server for remote storage, but it's clunky, it doesn't scrape PDF metadata very well, and it can't searchably, shareably, reversibly annotate PDFs (and this is an ABSOLUTE MUST for serious projects)
I use Mendeley when I'm Serious
Elsevier is starting hands of and letting them do their thing
Mendeley has fantastic BibTeX support, grabs metadata like a champ, end supports collaborative annotation and PDF sharing
It takes a lot for me to use something proprietary, but Zotero lacks too many critical features

text: I just started playing with it
<@U0C0XE7CZ|matt.s.curtis> has joined the channel
<@U0C0XE7CZ> and I were just talking about how Caltech is scared to use Google Apps for Education "for security reasons"
CurtisLab, GravesLab, and ClarkLab use it for absolutely everything
Lawrence Berkeley National Labs use it for absolutely everything
the groups on campus that don't use Google Apps (Drive) use Dropbox, which I can't imagine is really very different
The argument is that Google wouldn't agree to storing all data within the US.
We have Dropbox, because they agreed to store in the US.
I guess Google's architecture probably doesn't let them do that?
Or maybe they're just being honest and saying, "Well, if you open it from China..."
Didn't we even have DARPA stuff on CurtisLab?
yeah we did
Google drive is not technically export control compliant
Legally there is stuff you probably should store on there
Or risk serious fines and jail time.
As your local ITAR compliance officer I would recommend discussing options for more security options with your Google representative or investigating other services
Export control compliant... What does that actually mean?
export controls are legal limitations attached to certain advanced technologies that we don't want (certain) other countries to have
the government essentially steps in to limit who you can sell certain things to
for instance, you can't sell Baby's First Anthrax Farm to Iran, Syria, ...&etc
it also applies to the products of some research programs
in some cases, there can be no Iranian, Syrian, ...&etc nationals _in the room_ while you're sharing your research results
and you have to take every (un)reasonable precaution to keep the information away from any such person
<http://orc.osu.edu/regulations-policies/exportcontrol/>
That's the normal stuff. Like engineering software

Actual fun things are more restricted. You can sell or pass the information to people from other countries with sufficient paper work but god help you if you didn't fill out the paper work before even letting a foreign national into the same room where someone was working on missile diagrams etc.
So without fancy tokenized and isolator file structures and such your best bet is encrypted hard drives in locked rooms
<@U0A6XP8JF>: If you don't like Asana, check out Wunderlist.  It looks functionally identical, but with a potentially smoother/less ugly UI
(my supervisor is considering switching the lab to Wunderlist.  I thought he was really organized at first but it turns out he's just a serial tech-adopter.  Better than the alternative, I guess?)

also, I just remembered an older list-maker called Workflowy, which I haven't seen mentioned here-- it is a little less on the bells-and-whistles but may be more functional for some people on this thread as I think it allows more nesting of tasks.  Last time I used it was in 2012 though so no promises.

text: you would make a great personal assistant

<@U0A6T0LNT|brandon> uploaded a file: <https://gwusbdhdu.slack.com/files/brandon/F0DMQN9PH/bc-org-monday.png|bc-org-monday.png> and commented: here's today's section of "2015 Week 45"
my degree of templating has gone down over time

now I just keep what I've actually done in the top section, then a horizontal rule, then some of the stuff I want to get done that day, then a horizontal rule, then any copy-pasted bits of information that might come in handy on the scale of that day

the top section, 'Monday Morning Review': over the weekend I spend a few minutes looking over the previous week's document and skimming *|BC| Idea Mine* to formulate a rough list of targets for the week
*|BC| Idea Mine* is a hundred pages of several lifetimes' worth of 'interesting ideas'
it's broken up into 'Repeating Tasks', 'Big Projects', and 'Small Projects'
'repeating tasks' is a list of stuff that isn't really a project
financial reviews and client check-ins, various manual updates and backups, and stuff like 'fun places to hike/ride' that can't really be finished
*Small Projects* is stuff like 'Establish a Bitcoin-Powered ASCA'
'find/compile information on, and lists of, employee-owned and benefit corporations'
'cross-compilation in Linux'
small projects might only take a day or a week of concerted effort
10-100 hours to completion
a subsection of 'Small Projects' is, for instance, 'Calculations'
just a big list of calculations and visualizations that I think might help to understand something about the world
like 'grid energy lost to line resistance and transformers'
(related to an idea I have for a centralized, high-efficiency AC-DC switching power supply appliance for home use)
another section is 'Apps'
ideas for simple web apps that I think I could pull off with a little study
*Big Projects* is the cold-sweat-inducing section
the 'I already know I can never get all of this done' section
a Big Project is something like 'Personal Finance'
and for a Big Project, a reasonable goal is something like 'attain financial independence'
